entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 12 at 5:30AM AKST by NWS
entry.summary: ...3 To 5 Inches Of Snow Tonight Through Sunday... Snow is expected to develop this evening across the Central Interior and continue into Sunday evening. Between 3 and 5 inches of snow is expected by Sunday evening when the snow tapers off. In Fairbanks 3 to 4 inches of snow is expected, with 5 inches of
entry.cap:areaDesc: Central Interior; Deltana and Tanana Flats; Denali; Middle Tanana Valley

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 11 at 8:21PM AKST by NWS
entry.summary: ...Wind Chill near 60 Below... Wind Chill will hover in the 40 to 60 below range through the weekend. Cold temperatures continue in the Chukchi Sea and Norton Sound Regions with low temperatures in the 20s to 30s below, while high temperatures will be in the teens and 20s below.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Baldwin Peninsula and Selawik Valley; Chukchi Sea Coast; Lower Kobuk and Noatak Valleys; Northern and Interior Seward Peninsula; Upper Kobuk and Noatak Valleys

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 11 at 8:06PM AKST by NWS
entry.summary: ...Wind Chill near 60 Below... Wind Chill will hover in the 40 to 60 below range through the weekend. entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 12 at 10:15AM CST by NWS
entry.summary: ...Gusty north winds through late this afternoon... A strong cold front has moved through the region and north winds are increasing, especially across the Hill Country and for areas along the Interstate 35 corridor. A few locations could briefly see sustained winds near 25 mph along with gusts near 40 mph. Conditions will be monitored and a Wind Advisory may be issued.

Total snow accumulations of 3 to 6 inches, with up to 8 inches locally. * WHERE...Augusta County and the Central Virginia Blue Ridge. * WHEN...From 10 PM this evening to 4 PM EST Sunday.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued February 12 at 10:00AM EST until February 13 at 4:00PM EST by NWS
entry.summary: ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 1 AM TO 4 PM EST SUNDAY... * WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 1 to 2 inches, with up to 4 inches locally. * WHERE...Nelson County. * WHEN...From 1 AM to 4 PM EST Sunday.

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued February 12 at 12:53PM AST until February 14 at 6:00AM AST by NWS
entry.summary: ...HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE SUNDAY NIGHT... * WHAT...Dangerous rip currents expected due to breaking waves of 6 to 8 feet. * WHERE...Beaches of the northwest to northeast Puerto Rico, all beaches of Culebra, and beaches of northwest Saint Thomas.

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued February 12 at 12:53PM AST until February 14 at 6:00AM AST by NWS
entry.summary: ...HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE SUNDAY NIGHT... * WHAT...Dangerous rip currents expected due to breaking waves of 6 to 8 feet. * WHERE...Most beaches of Saint Croix. * WHEN...Through late Sunday night.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 12 at 12:13PM EST by NWS
entry.summary: ...Snow showers will impact portions of southeastern Essex, southern Addison, northwestern Rutland and southwestern Washington Counties through 100 PM EST... At 1212 PM EST, snow showers were reported along a line extending from near D A R State Park to near Chestertown. Movement was east at 25 mph.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Addison; Washington; Western Addison; Western Rutland

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued February 12 at 10:00AM EST until February 13 at 1:00PM EST by NWS
entry.summary: ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 10 PM THIS EVENING TO 1 PM EST SUNDAY... * WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 2 to 4 inches, with up to 6 inches locally. * WHERE...Portions of northwest and western Virginia and eastern West Virginia.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 12 at 9:55AM MST by NWS
entry.summary: ...Moderate Gusty West Winds Near Arlington and Elk Mountain Through 2 PM Today... Travelers on Interstate 80 between mile markers 240 and 290 can expect westerly wins of 30 to 35 mph sustained with gusts to 55 mph through 2 PM today. These stronger wind gusts will create patchy blowing and drifting snow at times before the winds ease
